article.body: Rated at 100 miles per gallon equivalent Starts just over $33,000 Eligible for federal tax credit Up to 37 miles electric-only range The latest powertrain offering in the recently revampedÂ 2020 Ford F, -1.36% Â EscapeÂ is also its most efficient, rated at an eye-popping 100 mpg. Technically the Ford EscapeÂ Plug-in HybridÂ earns 100 MPGe, with the last letter signaling âequivalentâ by the EPA. Thatâs the rating the government agency gives vehicles such as this when they use an electrified powertrain. Related: How to choose trim levels and options when buying a new car The Ford Escape is all new for 2020, and it already offers a hybrid model along with standard gasoline-only powertrains. The regular 2020 Ford Escape Hybrid earns an impressive 41 mpg combined. But thanks to its larger battery pack, the Ford Escape Plug-in Hybrid trounces that number for a class-leading 100 MPGe.Power and efficiency Like the standard Escape Hybrid, this plug-in model pairs a 2.5-literÂ 4-cylinder engineÂ with an electric motor good for a total of 200 horsepower. But the larger battery pack means the plug-in model can travel a sizable distance on electricity alone â up to 37 miles. Between the electrification and gasoline engine, the Ford Escape PHEVâs total range is EPA-rated at 530 miles. Ford says recharge times are 10-11 hours on a standard 110-volt outlet or under 3.5 hours on a Level 2, 240-volt line.Choice of three trims The 2020 Ford Escape Plug-in Hybrid is on sale now and available in three trims: SE (starting at $33,040, plus destination fee), SEL ($35,620), and Titanium ($36,435). These prices are several thousand dollars higher than the standard hybrid, but the PHEV also has potential cost savings beyond its enhanced efficiency. While the EPA has yet to announce the full tax credit incentive for the 2020 Escape PHEV, a similar sibling, the Ford Fusion Energi sedan, is eligible for a $4,609 credit. All models include standard safety features such as forward-collision warning with automatic emergency braking, lane-keeping assist and blind-spot monitoring.Â Apple AAPL, +1.74% Â CarPlayÂ and Android Auto integration is also included. Top-tier Titanium models boast amenities likeÂ adaptive cruise control, Bang & Olufsen premium audio, leather interior and 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster.New territory for SUVs While hybrid SUVs have been around a while â in fact, the originalÂ first-gen Escape HybridÂ was the worldâs first hybrid sport-utility vehicle when it made its debut 15 years ago â plug-in hybrid SUVs relatively new. The Ford Escape PHEV recently went on sale, and what looks to be a formidable competitor is just around the corner. Unlike the Ford Escape PHEV that is front-wheel drive only, the Toyota RAV4 Prime is all-wheel drive. (The standard Ford Escape Hybrid also offers AWD.) The Toyota packs much more power â 302 hp â and Toyota says the RAV4 Prime will do 0-60 mph in just 5.7 seconds. Plus, the RAV4 Prime is estimated to go up 42 miles on electricity alone â 5 more than the Ford.
